bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, October 23, 1894

div1.p: Carter discusses his family and his orange grove in Florida.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, October 23, 1894
div1.p:
No one wrote last Sunday because we
(L. Jr. Magruder & I,) went on an excursion to
East Key -- 4 miles off after shells &
I came back with a most awful headache
so that I was no account all yesterday.

I am going over to to key West. Quaran-
tine to night to be had tomorrow night- & it
may be that after this time El Forten can go to the
Dock & me get ashave- Our Q. is over Nov. 1st but
Fla holds to Nov 15 However that is nearly here.
How L. is to get away is to leave this fall, is a
problem to me, rough is the name for the water
from this place to Key West & thence to Tampa-two
trips are of 8. or 10 & the other of 20 to 24 hours.
However we would pick as nice a day as we
could, & by watching our chance might get through. There
has been no calm day however - since the hurricane,
L. is very well & so are the children. I will have
more time now & am beginning Laura's French
& arithmetic, Henry is reading very fairly,
& Ned has quite a turn for his books, especially
C1
B23
for writing & making figures.

H. has an air gun & has killed 5 (& Laura
1) birds this week shoots #1 shot.
I do not know whether it is too late to fish now or
not; have not been for a long time & in rough water
it is the reverse of pleasant to be dancing about in a
small boat. We got a lot of pretty shells on the keys
There is no comparison between the beauty of the shells
here & at Chandeleur - although except rose Conches-
there are more shells at Chandeleur. And crab-
I thought that when we found 11 kinds at Chandeleur
we had enough. But here unless we suppose varieties
sport, like seed fruit.- I should say that I have seen
100 kinds. The spotted (“leopard”) crabs live
here. none to eat however - the more is the pity,
& fish too are decidedly scarce-oysters unknown
so as an eating place it is inferior to Chandeleur,
I am not sorry to have seen it & will be glad to leave
it. I almost expect however it would be better for
me to stay here this winter for the children's sake
To think of going through a winter without a sore
throat or bad-cold for the 4 (L. Sr.) of them?
It is worth something. It will be too late any
way to put them to school when I can get ashore
to do any good & they will learn as much here
as else where. They should have fairly developed
ideas of geography any way & know no little
about somethings. I wish they had a home
however.

After Quarantine, we will have but
two regular mails per week although
we may occasionally get off on a fishing
much. Rev. cutter or light house Tender, in
between times.

I am hoping to go up to Tampa to see my
Orange grove in November- It costs$24.00$21.00
K. W. to Tampa. & return. So I can make
the return trip for about $40.00 may
be $50.00. I hear that the place is doing
fairly well. To bring on the 23 acres of
young trees& costs about $150, per annum
more than the old grove yields - although last
year. - I came out 16 cents ahead, & that is doing
well, I have 25 acres in all you know, & the
C1
B23
old grove clears about $50.00 per acre over its own expenses one year -
with another I have 27 more trees bearing next year
than I have had - old trees that were moved so
it may increase about $15.00 per annum,
I hope so.

I suspect that Buchmaster (at the U. of Va.) is a good ap-
pointee. He is editor of a well edited journal,
which generally means enterprise ability & not much prac-
tice. At any rate it is well to break the tradi-
tion they have fallen into - of only appointing
their own men. Christian, I am sure, is a bad
appointment.

I wish I could spend this fall at home, Mother
I believe the happiest time I have had for
years was the fall (part of November only) I spent
at North River with L. & the children before I went
to Savannah.

Ed was delighted with
his letter
